*[Bug 17148] rasterImage shows incorrect image orientation (MacOSX)*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17148>

Simon Urbanek (<mailto:simon.urbanek@r-project.org|simon.urbanek@r-project.org>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |simon.urbanek@r-project.org

--- Comment #14 from Simon Urbanek (<mailto:simon.urbanek@r-project.org|simon.urbanek@r-project.org>) ---
Currently the behaviour for flipped images is undefined, i.e., it is expected
that left < right and bottom < top. So what we need to define is what should
happen in cases the those constraints are violated.

I think I have convinced myself that the current behaviour of cairo is
defensible as a good precedent: it interprets the left/bottom/right/top
relative to the sides of the **original** image, i.e. (`xleft`, `ybottom`) is
the location of the bottom left corner of the original image and (`xright`,
`ytop`) of the top-right corner. If the position violates the relative location
then it treats the image as a transparent film and will flip it accordingly.
Finally, the rotation happens only at the end and will be always
counter-clockwise around the (`xleft`, `ybottom`) point. The last point is
actually documented so not controversial.

I have made Quartz now consistent with those rules in R-devel in r89178 (so the
macOS part is now fixed), but it would be nice to update the documentation to
define the currently undefined behaviour - and then make all devices consistent
including X11 and Windows.
